The physical exam and symptoms (pallor, tiredness, picky eater, and love for whole milk) suggest that the patient might have an iron-poor diet. It is recommended to limit milk intake as it can interfere with the absorption of iron. Administering deferoxamine is used to treat iron overload rather than iron-deficiency anemia. An echocardiogram is not necessary at this point as the patient’s symptoms and physical findings suggest iron-deficiency anemia. Measuring folate level is not necessary as folate deficiency is not the most likely cause of the patient’s anemia.

An echocardiogram may be indicated if there is concern for a structural heart defect, but the grade II systolic ejection murmur is most likely due to anemia. Administering deferoxamine is used to treat iron overload, which is not the case in this patient. Measuring folate level is not necessary as the patient’s anemia is likely due to iron deficiency. Therefore, the next best step in management for this patient’s diagnosis is to limit milk intake and emphasize iron-rich foods in the diet or iron supplementation if necessary.
